newsitem.title: JAPAN: JSkyB says in talks with Fuji TV on capital tie-up.
newsitem.headline: JSkyB says in talks with Fuji TV on capital tie-up.

text.p: Japan Sky Broadcasting Corp (JSkyB) is in talks with Japanese terrestrial broadcasting company Fuji Television on its possible capital participation in JSkyB, a JSkyB spokesman told Reuters on Friday.
JSkyB is also talking with Walt Disney Co and several Japanese terrestrial broadcasters other than Fuji TV on content supply and possible capital participation in JSkyB, the spokesman said.
"But Fuji TV in particular has a strong interest in taking a stake in JSkyB," he said.
JSkyB is a satellite broadcasting venture already linking Softbank Corp, News Corp Ltd and Sony Corp.
JSkyB hopes to complete talks with Fuji TV as early as possible, or at least during News Corp chairman Rupert Murdoch's visit to Japan next week, he said.
Murdoch is to visit Japan on May 14 to make a keynote speech at the World Congress of the International Federation of the Periodical Press on May 15.
Murdoch is expected to stay in Japan for two or three days, he said.
Fuji Television is to go public on the Tokyo Stock Exchange this autumn.
JSkyB will start test-beaming in Japan this spring and aims to offer 150 channels in spring 1998.
Although Softbank president Masayoshi Son has said Softbank News Corp Sony will own equal stakes in JSkyB, an announcement has been delayed.
The talks with terrestrial broadcasters are in line with media tycoon Murdoch's policy of providing local-language content in its satellite broadcasting programmes, the spokesman said.
But media reports said Murdoch had difficulties convincing Japanese broadcasters to supply content to JSkyB until Sony early this year announced its participation in JSkyB.

Tough competition for subscribers is expected this autumn when Hughes Electronics Corp group's DirecTV plans to start a 100-channel service. Japan's PerfecTV started a multi-channel satellite broadcasting service last year.
